entry.title: Custom Situation Handling in Quality Management: Get Notified when an Inspection Lot is Created
entry.content:
Use Case: ‚ÄúCreate Custom Situation Type for notifying users when an inspection lot is created‚Äù.

Even though standards apps are available which can be used to check the inspections lots created for the day. However, due to nature of the business role/responsibilities and frequency of inspection process, some users(customers) want the system to notify them via situation handling.

This blog is a detailed guide for configuring a custom situation type in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to notify users when an inspection lot is created. Here's a structured summary of the key concepts and steps:

Objective

Enable notifications (SAP Fiori home screen + email) when an inspection lot is created using Situation Handling ‚Äì Extended Framework.

Solution Overview

  • Customizable for specific business scenarios.
  • Notifications triggered by events (e.g., inspection lot creation).
  • Delivered via SAP Fiori and email.

After setting up the custom situation type, users will be able to receive notifications on their SAP home screen and via email.

 

 

Prerequisites

Apps Required:

  • Manage Situation Objects
  • Manage Teams and Responsibilities
  • Manage Responsibility Contexts
  • Manage Situation Scenarios
  • Manage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended

Roles Required:

  • BR_BUSINESS_PROCESS_SPEC
  • BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC
  • BR_ADMINISTRATOR
  • BR_BPC_EXPERT
  • BR_EMPLOYEE
  • BR_EMPLOYEE_MAINTENANC

These are default SAP roles. Custom roles depend on the authorization concept can be set-up in the specific system.

Step-by-Step Setup

Key Concept: Basic steps for creating a custom situation type in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition are outlined in the pictures below. Users can create their own situation use cases with the extended framework for Situation Handling.  The extended framework offers three new configuration apps: Mange Situation Objects, Manage Situation Scenarios, and Manage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended.

The following image illustrates the activities associated with the respective applications.

 

Step 1: Create Situation Objects

With this app, users can model business objects that facilitate Situation Handling. A situation object connects existing application artifacts, such as CDS views, events, and actions, which serve as the foundation for establishing situation use cases.

Use ‚ÄúManage Situation Objects‚Äù app.

  • Create object ID (Picture 1)
  • Use CDS view I_INSPECTIONLOT.
  • Define Structures: (Picture 2)
    • Set semantic keys and personal data fields. (Picture 2)
  • Define Events, anchor and trigger objects (Picture 3). In general anchor and trigger object are established on the situation scenario level. e.g. Inspection lot creation
    • In this situation, the anchor and trigger are the same, i.e. the inspection lot
  • Define navigation & actions (Picture 4 &5). The event corresponds to the modeled object created earlier and can be used as triggers.

(Picture 1)

(Picture 2)

(Picture 3)

(Picture 4)

While generic IDs like NAV01 are possible, the recommended naming would reflect the object and navigation target, e.g. YY1_NAV_MANAGE_INS_LOT.

(Picture 5)

While generic IDs like ACT1 are possible, the recommended naming would reflect the object and Action, e.g. YY1_ACT_MANAGE_INS_LOT.

For further information refer to : https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/d973eb6d464d4dce84f354b9668ef43c.html

 

Step 2: Create Responsibility Context

Manage Responsibility Contexts in SAP lets you view, use, and extend standard or custom contexts that define who is responsible for business tasks across workflows and situation handling. A responsibility context links specific business processes or objects (like inspection lot) with rules or teams to determine the responsible agents. You can extend standard contexts or create custom ones with tailored agent rules, enabling precise assignment of responsibilities to individuals or teams for better workflow and process management.

A team is defined in the app ‚ÄòManage Teams and Responsibilities‚Äô whereas Team category is assigned in the app ‚ÄôManage Responsibility Context‚Äô. Using configuration ‚ÄòDefine Team Types‚Äô the mapping of team type and team category is done.

  • Create team in ‚ÄúManage Teams and Responsibilities‚Äù.
  • Define context in ‚ÄúManage Responsibility Contexts‚Äù.(Picture 7 &'8)
    • Add team category. (Picture 6 &'8)

(Picture 6 ‚Äì Concept)

(Picture 7)

(Picture '8)

For further information refer to the blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/responsibility-management-what-is-it-and-why-do-you-need-it-1-5/ba-p/13713337

 

Step 3: Create Situation Scenario

This app helps to create your own scenarios for extended object-based situations. These are situations that occur for a specific business object, like an inspection lot. A situation scenario is a technical description of a business scenario and serves as the foundation for defining multiple use cases in the form of situation templates. 

A situation scenario consists of one anchor object and one/more trigger objects. An anchor object is the object that is affected by a situation, such as an inspection lot. A trigger object creates an impact that results in situation instances for the anchor object, such as creation of an inspection lot.

Use ‚ÄúManage Situation Scenarios‚Äù.

  • Define scenario ID, type (Object-based), and structure (CDS). (Picture 9)
  • Select the anchor object and anchor object structure (Picture 9)
  • Add the instance key, i.e. the anchor object. (Picture 10)
  • Define List page layout (Picture 10).
  • Define general and specific actions. (Picture 11)
  • Define parameters for situation triggers (Picture 12 & 13) ‚Äì It can be triggered via events (e.g when inspection lot is created) or using batch jobs (e.g. running batch jobs every few hours to notify users on the created inspection lots)
  • Define Situation Page (Picture 13A) - Here user can select the field which should be populated in the notification details.

(Picture 9)

(Picture 10)

(Picture 11)

(Picture 12)

(Picture 13)

(Picture 13A)

For further information refer to: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/dfac958be2af4ce79589e8a3eaff88d6.html

 

Step 4: Create Team

This app allows users to manage teams, define responsibilities, and assign functions to team members in the Responsibility Management section. By using responsibility definitions and member functions, you can identify the members (recipients) who are responsible for workflows, business scenarios, and handling situations.

Use ‚ÄúManage Teams and Responsibility‚Äù.

  • Assign team type. The category will be automatically filled. (Picture 14)
  • Responsibility parameters will be populated automatically based on the configuration ‚ÄòAssign Custom Responsibility Definition‚Äô SSCUI- 102159 (e.g., plant)
  • Assign member functions for notification routing. The members are also not only for receiving notifications, but also for those who gets to see situations/situation instances in the app ‚ÄòMy Situations ‚Äì Extended‚Äô

(Picture 14)

For further information refer to: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/73c04858392e9244e10000000a4450e5.html

 

Step 5: Create Situation Template

Situation templates are used to define and standardize the monitoring of specific business exceptions or critical situations. These templates act as blueprints for different situation types.

Use ‚ÄúManage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended‚Äù.

  • Define template ID, scenario, and triggers. (Picture 15)
  • Choose if user needs the instances to be kept (Picture 16)
  • Set General Actions (Picture 17)
  • Define situation Triggers (Picture 18)
    • Set conditions and filters. (Picture 19, 20) e.g. Inspection type
    • Configure display and notification texts. (Picture 21)
    • Optional: define navigation actions. (Picture 22)

(Picture 15)

(Picture ‚Äì 16)

(Picture ‚Äì 17)

(Picture ‚Äì 18)

(Picture ‚Äì 19)

(Picture ‚Äì 20)

(Picture 21)

(Picture ‚Äì 22)

For further information refer to:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/45d60edcf02d409c87076f9270372eb8.html

 

Step 6: Create Situation Type

Situation types describe a business situation that defines how a situation instance is triggered and who is informed about it. In the extended framework for Situation Handling, the configuration of a situation type also includes the definition of actions for solving a situation. These situations are automatically detected and addressed by identifying and handling critical events or exceptions within business processes. Situation types are derived from templates and offer customization options for conditions, notifications, responsible users, and informative texts for users. Upon activation, they generate situation instances that promptly notify the designated users, thereby enhancing process efficiency and decision-making.

Use ‚ÄúManage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended‚Äù.

  • Create situation type by copying the template created in the previous step.
  • Enable status. (Picture 23)
  • Triggers, actions, and recipients (processors) are copied from the template. For batch trigger a recurrence must be defined here. (Picture 24)
  • Use Teams or rules for processor assignment.

(Picture 23)

(Picture ‚Äì 24)

Here is an overview of the modelled custom situation template & type for this use case

(Picture ‚Äì 25)

Our recommendation is to not create IDs with spaces, so the ID would better be YY1_INSPECTION_LOT_CREATED

For further information refer to:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/45d60edcf02d409c87076f9270372eb8.html

 

Step 7: Test

  • Create inspection lot manually or via goods receipt.
  • Check notifications
    • in home screen (Picture 26, 28)
    • bell icon (Picture 27, 28)
    • Email (if Email notification is enabled in the user settings) (Picture 29)
    • ‚ÄúMy Situations ‚Äì Extended‚Äù app (Picture 30)

(Picture 26)

 

(Picture 27)

 If users navigate from the notification

 

(Picture 28)

  • Description (comes from situation type)
  • Usage decision information (comes from situation scenario > situation page layout)
  • Related apps (button comes from defined actions from situation objects, detailed in situation scenario, situation template and type) 

(Picture 29)

 

(Picture 30)

 In each step only necessary information has been provided without over describing it. But to further help the readers we have provided all the necessary SAP Help links to set up their own situation handling scenario easily. 

Hope you will be able to set up your own custom situation.

entry.title: Subscription Management for Software (5SW)
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs software-driven business environment, subscription-based models are increasingly the norm. Managing subscriptions, entitlements, usage, billing  and revenue recognition can become complex without a robust system in place. SAP addresses this challenge with an integrated end-to-end process across SAP Cloud ERP, SAP Subscription Billing, and SAP Entitlement Management. This solution simplifies subscription management while enabling automation and comprehensive insights into software usage and revenue.

With 2508 release SAP has provided an end-2-end Best Practice content for Software and SaaS use cases. The goal of this Best Practice is to significantly reduce time-to-value by providing clear setup instructions for common processes along the end-2-end value chain. The Best Practice content is provided via the new scope item 5SW (link to scope item in the Process Navigator).

 

What does Scope Item 5SW cover?

This scope item enables a seamless process for the full lifecycle of software subscriptions. From subscription modeling and pricing to fulfillment, billing, and revenue recognition, the integration ensures all steps are connected:

  • Subscription Modeling & Pricing: Define software subscription products, base and add-on licenses, and pricing models.
  • Sales & Fulfillment: Sell subscriptions through solution orders in SAP Cloud ERP and manage provisioning in SAP Entitlement Management.
  • License & Usage Management: Track entitlements, license consumption, and software usage to ensure compliance and optimize revenue.
  • Billing & Revenue Recognition: Automate billing for recurring, one-time, and usage-based charges, and ensure accurate revenue recognition.
  • End-of-Life Processes: Decommission licenses and tenants at the end of subscription contracts efficiently.

This scope item consolidates several existing capabilities, including Subscription Management with Sales Billing, corresponding capabilities of Solution Order Management, and Event-Based Revenue Recognition, Subscription Billing, extended with SAP Entitlement Management functionalities.

Key Process Flow

Process Flow

  1. Creation or Update of the Solution Order
    The Solution Order Specialist initiates the process by creating a new Solution Order or updating an existing one. This serves as the foundation for all subsequent subscription and billing activities.
  2. Automatic Subscription Creation in SAP Subscription Billing
    If the Solution Order includes a subscription item, a corresponding subscription is automatically created in SAP Subscription Billing with a pending status. This ensures that the subscription lifecycle is immediately tracked and initialized.
  3. Entitlement Assignment and Provisioning
    In SAP Entitlement Management, entitlements can be added to the subscription to define the customer‚Äôs access rights. Once entitlements are assigned, tenant and license provisioning are triggered to enable the actual usage.
  4. Subscription Finalization and Activation
    After entitlement configuration and provisioning, the subscription is finalized and activated. This marks the transition from setup to operational use.
  5. Automatic Creation of Provider Contract and Billing Plan
    With the subscription activated, SAP Cloud ERP automatically generates the Provider Contract and the associated billing plan. These define the contractual framework and scheduling for invoicing.
  6. Revenue Recognition
    Based on the activated subscription and billing data, Revenue Recognition can be monitored in the SAP Cloud ERP system.

 

  1. Detection of Billing Cycle End
    Once the end of the billing cycle is detected, the process for capturing license usage begins. In SAP Entitlement Management, both software consumption and actual license utilization are recorded.
  2. Transfer and Rating of Usage Data
    The recorded usage data is automatically sent to SAP Subscription Billing. There, it is rated according to the predefined price models and tariff rules.
  3. Automatic Billing in SAP Subscription Billing
    Based on the consumed quantity and the billing cycle, SAP Subscription Billing automatically generates bills. This eliminates manual effort and ensures consistent and rule-based billing.
  4. Creation of Billing Document Request (BDR)
    The generated bills are transferred to SAP Cloud ERP, where a Billing Document Request (BDR) is created. This serves as the foundation for further processing in the ERP system.
  5. Generation of Billing Documents
    Using the BDR, the final Billing Documents are created in SAP Cloud ERP. They contain all relevant billing information and can be used for financial posting and customer communication.
  6. Event-Based Revenue Recognition
    Finally, event-based Revenue Recognition is executed. This ensures that revenue is posted in compliance with accounting standards, enabling accurate financial reporting.

  1. Decommissioning of Tenants and Licenses
    Once the subscription contract reaches its end, the associated tenants and licenses can be properly decommissioned. This ensures that access is revoked, resources are released, and the offboarding process is completed in a controlled manner.

 

Business Benefits

Implementing this integrated scope item delivers significant advantages:

  • End-to-End Automation: Streamline modelling, selling, fulfillment, and billing of software subscriptions.
  • Flexible License Management: Use generic license templates for multiple applications, tenant types, and metrics.
  • Efficient Provisioning & Updates: Automate updates, add-ons, and decommissioning of licenses and tenants.
  • Usage Insights: Monitor adoption, detect low, and prevent revenue leakage from overuse.
  • Flexible Billing Models: Support recurring, one-time, and usage-based billing.
  • Integrated Revenue Recognition: Ensure compliance and accuracy in multi-license scenarios.

Conclusion

By combining SAP Cloud ERP, SAP Subscription Billing, and SAP Entitlement Management, businesses can achieve a fully integrated, automated subscription management process to explicitly cover common requirements of software & SaaS use cases. This approach not only reduces operational complexity but also enhances visibility into software usage, adoption, and revenue‚Äîempowering companies to maximize value from their subscription offerings.

For further information or any questions, you can reach out to me:

Faruk Gedik (Business Process Consultant), faruk.gedik@sap.com

and I will be happy to assist you.

entry.title: A Practical Guide to Extending Standard Billing Forms in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
One of the most frequent topics customers seek guidance on is how they can tailor their business documents to reflect their unique brand and operational needs. While the standard forms we deliver are a fantastic starting point, your billing document is a key touchpoint with your customers, and it needs to be just right.

Today, I‚Äôm going to walk you through a practical, step-by-step guide on how to extend the standard billing document form template to meet some of the most common business requirements. We'll cover adding your company logo, including standard and custom fields, adding static text, and even generating multiple copies such as customer copy or archive copy of a single invoice.

Let‚Äôs get started!

The Core Tools of the Trade

Before we dive into the details, let's familiarize ourselves with the key applications and tools we will be using in the SAP Fiori launchpad:

1. Maintain Form Templates App: This is your central hub for managing all form templates. Here, you can copy standard templates, download the layout files, upload your modified versions, and activate them.
2. Custom Fields App: A powerful application that allows you to create your own business-specific fields and make them available in various business contexts, including form templates.
3. Output Parameter Determination App: After you have a beautiful new form, this app is where you define the business rules that tell the system when to use it (e.g., for a specific company code, sales organization, or customer).

Adobe LiveCycle Designer: This is the design tool used to edit the visual layout of the form. You will need to have it installed on your local machine (available via app Install Additional Software).


Step 1: Create Your Custom Form Template

SAP delivers default form templates that you can copy to create your own custom form templates

1. Open the Maintain Form Templates app, and navigate to the Predelivered Templates tab..
2. Search for SDBIL_CI_STANDARD* to find the standard templates for customer invoices.You will see localized versions like ‚ÄúSDBIL_CI_STANDARD_US‚Äù or ‚ÄúSDBIL_CI_STANDARD_DE‚Äù.
3. Select the standard template that best fits your region and select Copy.
4. Give your new template a name. For example: `YY1_MYCORP_BILLING_FORM_US`.
5. Click OK.


Step 2: Download the Layout and Make Basic Changes

Now that you have your custom copy, let's download the layout file and add some fundamental customizations.

1. On the Custom Templates tab, search for your new template.

2. Open the form template, then select Download.

3 Save and extract the zip archive. The archive contains the form template as an XDP file, data provider information in XSD format, and optionally, the form template master, also as an XDP file.

You are now in the design environment. On the left, you'll see the `Hierarchy` and `Data View` tabs. The `Data View` shows all the data fields available from the system, while the `Hierarchy` shows the structure of the form itself.


Common Requirement: Adding a Company Logo

The recommended way to manage logos in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with the Manage Logos app. You upload your logo there and it gets a unique name. The form can then pull it dynamically.

1. Open the XDP file via Adobe LiveCycle Designer

2. In LiveCycle Designer, find the placeholder for the logo (it's often an Image Field object at the top).
3. Select the Image Field and go to the Object  palette.
4. Ensure the Embed Image Data option is unchecked.
5. Go to the Binding palette. You should see a binding reference like `$record.Form_Header.Logo.URL`. This tells the form to fetch the logo URL provided by the system. By using the Manage Logos app and this binding will work automatically.


Common Requirement: Adding Static Text (e.g., Terms & Conditions)

1. In the Hierarchy view, find the content area where you want to add the text (e.g., `contentArea`).
2. Drag a Text object from the Object Library onto your form's design view.
3. Double-click the new text object and type or paste your terms and conditions.
4. In the Layout palette, make sure the Expand to Fit options are checked so the text block can grow as needed.

Step 3: Extending the Form with Custom Fields

This is where the real power of extensibility shines. Let's say you need to add a "Project Manager" name to your billing documents, a field that doesn't exist in the standard system.

Part A: Create the Custom Field in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

1. Open the Custom Fields app.
2. Click the +icon to create a new field.
3. Select the Select the business context Sales: Billing Document. This is crucial as it determines where the field can be used.
4. Provide a label for your field (e.g., ‚ÄúProject Manager‚Äù). Based on the label, the system suggests an identifier, for example, ‚ÄúYY1_ProjectManager
5. Choose a Type, such as `Text`, and set the length.
6. Navigate to the Form Templates tab. Find the data source and check the Enable Usage box.
7. (Recommended) Navigate to the User Interfaces tab. Enable the field for `Manage Billing Documents` and `Create Billing Documents` (business context - Sales: Billing Due List) so you can see and edit it directly in the Fiori apps.
8. Save and Publish your field. This process can take a few minutes.


Part B: Update the Form Data Source and Layout

1. Go back to the Maintain Form Templates app.
2. Open your custom template (`YY1_MYCORP_BILLING_FORM_US`).
3. Download the form template again. This is a critical step! Downloading the template again ensures the XDP 's schema is updated with the new custom field you just published.
4. Open the new XDP file in Adobe LiveCycle Designer.
5. Go to the Data View tab. Expand the nodes to find your new field, YY1_ProjectManager.

6.Drag your new field from the `Data View` and drop it onto the form canvas where you want it to appear. A caption and a text field will be created automatically.
7. Style and position the new field to match the rest of your form.

Step 4: Upload and Activate Your Masterpiece

Once you are happy with all your changes, it's time to upload the form back into the system.

1. Save your XDP file in Adobe LiveCycle Designer.

2. Return to the Maintain Form Templates app in the SAP Fiori launchpad.

3. On the Custom Templates tab, choose New.

4. In the Create Form Template window, enter the form template name.

5. To specify the location of the custom template XDP, choose Browse.

6. From the Data Provider dropdown list, select FDP_V3_BD_STANDARD_SRV.

7. To generate the custom template, choose OK.

8. Finally, assign the form to a Business Context using configuration activity: Assign Form Templates. Your form is now live and ready to be used.

Step 5: Define When to Use Your New Form

The last step is to tell the system the business rules for when to use your new form. This is done in the Output Parameter Determination app.

1. Open the app and select Billing Document from the Show Rules for dropdown.
2. Select the Form Template determination step.
3. In edit mode, create a new rule in the Decision Table. You can set conditions like: use `YY1_MYCORP_BILLING_FORM_US` IF `Company Code` is `1010`, or IF `Sales Organization` is `US01`.
4. Activate the new rule.

 

Common Requirement: Generate multiple output items ‚Äì KBA 2757763 - How to print to multiple print queues or generate multiple output items.

Now, when a billing document is created that matches your conditions, the system will automatically use your beautifully customized form template.

Bonus tip on optimized handling of large data files :

In certain business processes, the form data XML can get too large and form rendering is rejected from the Adobe Document Services.
In such cases, you can try the following options to reduce the size of the form data XML:

‚Ä¢ Use the 'Untag PDF' option in the 'Assign Form Templates' configuration activity.
Depending on your configuration environment, you do configuration activities in either the Manage Your Solution app or in SAP Central Business Configuration. To access the documentation for configuration activities, open the Actions menu and select 'Configuration Help' (for Manage Your Solution) or choose 'Open Documentation' in the documentation column (for Central Business Configuration).

‚Ä¢ Use the 'Optimize data service' option in the 'Maintain Form Templates' app.
By default, during form rendering all data fields contained in the form data provider are sent to the Adobe Document Services for rendering. When enabling the newly introduced flag: Optimize data service the underlying template source will be statically analyzed. Only data fields that are directly used in a data binding by form elements will be transferred. This reduces the data transfer volume and improve the rendering performance.

Note that only data fields that are bound to an element in the form template will be detected and kept. Data fields that are only accessed via scripting are not supported. You can check existing data bindings by using the data view control in the Adobe LiveCycle Designer for SAP Solutions.

SAP recommends testing the output by generating a preview when enabling this feature.


Further Reading

For more in-depth information, please refer to these official resources:

* Setting Up Output Management - 1LQ Set Up Guide

* SAP Community : How to Bring Custom Fields to Billing Document Output (Video Tutorial)

* SAP Help Portal: Manage Your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition -> Document and Output Management

* SAP Help Portal : Output Management for Sales Documents and Billing Process Documents

* KBA 2984817 - Form design in Adobe LiveCycle Designer


I hope this guide empowers you to take control of your form templates. Customizing your business documents is a fantastic way to improve communication with your customers and streamline your own internal processes.

Happy customizing!

entry.title: Articulation relationship of Balance Sheet/Income Statements is uneven
entry.content:
‰∏Ä.What is the Balancing Relationship?
The balancing relationship refers to the interconnections between numbers within accounting ledgers and financial statements that allow for mutual examination and verification. It forms the core of the accounting equation, which ensures the internal consistency of financial statements. In essence, whenever there is an increase in any asset, it must be matched by a corresponding increase in liabilities or owners' equity, or by a decrease in another asset. Similarly, every increase in liabilities must be mirrored by an increase in assets or a decrease in owners' equity.
This balancing act is crucial for companies to ensure that their recorded financial information is both complete and precise, accurately reflecting the true financial position. By regularly examining these relationships, financial personnel can verify the correctness of the balance sheet and identify potential errors or omissions.

‰∫å.Why is it Important?
The balancing relationship is more than just numbers on a page; it is a critical tool for maintaining the integrity of financial data. For businesses, it means that stakeholders can trust the information presented, which is essential for decision-making, compliance, and overall financial health. Mistakes in financial data can lead to poor strategic decisions, legal penalties, or damaged reputations.
In conclusion, understanding and maintaining the balancing relationship within financial statements is not merely about fulfilling accounting obligations‚Äîit is about fostering trust and transparency. As financial landscapes become more complex, mastering these fundamentals will continue to be vital for all companies striving for accuracy and integrity in their reporting.

‰∏â.How to Check Why the Balancing Relationship is Not Equilibrated?

Open the app "Balance Sheet/Income Statement" or app "Balance Sheet / Income Statement - China" and find the field Unassigned Accounts. Export these accounts under the tab Unassigned Accounts to spreadsheet (for example, Microsoft Excel), filter with ‚ÄúFunctional Area‚Äù, and then do the following checks first:

1)Check whether the sum of manufacturing expense accounts (G/L accounts with functional area ‚Äúmanufacturing‚Äù) is 0. If it is not 0, carry forward to 0.
a)Open App Journal Entry Analyzer.
b)Input company code, fiscal year and period.
c)Only put "Functional Area" in Rows. Normally the production functional area should be YB20. If the balance for YB20 is zero, it means that the accounts for production should be balanced.
d)If there is balance, you can release the field "Order ID" and check for which exact order is with balance. Afterwards, you could make analysis on the specific order.

Balance between currencies

a)Normally the activity type revaluation will only ensure the global currency is balanced.
If you are using different currencies for global and company code currency, there might be balance in company code currency.
b)One more thing to consider is that you should make sure there is no "Not Distributed/Not Allocated" value after material ledger closing. You can check the same via app Material Value Flow Monitor.
c)If you maintain manual activity prices. You need to maintain the correct manual activity price with correct price unit and in the correct expected currency.
d)In Edit Actual Costing Run, make sure you set option "Process again".
e)To solve the Not Distributed value in global currency, you should tick "No stock coverage check" in Settlement step of Edit Actual Costing Run.

2)Check whether there are sales expenses, management expenses and R&D expenses (G/L accounts with functional areas ‚Äúsales/management/R&D‚Äù) in the unassigned accounts. If there are, the sum of balance should be 0. If the sum is not 0, assign them to FSV nodes.

3)Open the app "Manage Global Hierarchies" or the or the configuration activity Define Financial Statement VersionsÔºàID:102669) and open the financial statement version for Balance Sheet and Income Statement that you have defined for your company, double check whether there are any unreasonable configurations, for example, P&L accounts are assigned under FSV nodes in Balance Sheet; only Dr. or Cr. Indicator is selected for certain G/L accounts, but actually both debit and credit postings exist.

Hope the information could help you!

Best regards,

Lola

Business Scenarios

In the previous blog, Using Settlement Account for Non-Material Receivers in Production Order Settlement, we discussed and illustrated production order settlement to a cost center; however, the settlement account was a 2nd cost element, and it needed to be included in the financial report to reflect the expenses in income statement. What if we want to settle the costs to cost centers via primary cost elements. Maintain order settlement rule as WBS element Category with previous created WBS element

entry.title: Understanding Validity Periods in Manage Profit Centers: Operations, Limitations and Auto-Adjustment
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Purpose of Profit Center Validity Periods
  • Types of Validity Periods
  • Core Operations
  • Create
  • Update
  • Delete
  • Limitations
  • Automatic Adjustments
  • Splitting
  • Merging
  • Conclusion

Introduction

A validity period represents the timeframe during which master data is valid and can be used in business transactions. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, validity periods define when specific master data objects (such as profit centers, cost centers, or activity types) are active and applicable for postings, reporting, and planning.

Purpose of Profit Center Validity Periods

Validity periods help ensure accuracy and integrity of controlling master data by supporting:

  • Organizational changes ‚Äì maintain structure changes without losing historical records
  • Time accuracy ‚Äì ensure correct master data applies within the correct timeframe
  • Auditability ‚Äì provide a complete historical trail for compliance and audits
  • Future planning ‚Äì schedule structural changes with a future start date

Note: Key components include Valid From (start date), Valid To (end date), and Time-based fields (attributes specific to a validity period)

Types of Validity Periods

  • Active Period ‚Äì period currently used for postings
  • Future Period ‚Äì upcoming period planned in advance
  • Historical Period ‚Äì past configurations retained for reporting and audits

Core Operations

To demonstrate the basic work with validity periods within the Manage Profit Centers app, three simple cases are shown below: Create, Update, and Delete.

Create

Creating a new profit center requires completing mandatory master data fields (Profit Center, Profit Center Name, Valid From / Valid To, Person Responsible, Standard Hierarchy Node and Segment). Once the profit center is created, the system automatically generates its first validity period.

Note: When creating additional validity periods, system rules must be followed (see Limitations)

Example:

  • Valid From: 11/01/2025
  • Valid To: 12/31/2025‚ÄÉ

Create Operation

Update

A validity period already exists; however, when dates need to be adjusted (for example, extending the end date), the user can modify these fields directly in edit mode. Extending a period is always allowed if no limitations are violated.

Note: Shortening is restricted when postings exist (see Limitations)

Example:

  • Valid From: 11/01/2025
  • Valid To: 12/31/2025
  • Valid To (New): 12/31/2026

Update Operation

Delete

Although deletion is less commonly used (users are often cautious about removing master data), it is still possible to delete a validity period under strict conditions - primarily the absence of postings.

Note: If postings exist within the fiscal year, deletion is not allowed (see Limitations)

Delete Operation

Limitations

To ensure data consistency, correct reporting, and reliable controlling processes, several rules restrict how validity periods can be created, modified, or deleted. You can edit validity periods for profit centers, but the changes you're allowed to make depend on the following attributes:

Profit Center Attribute

Validity Period Rules

Multiple validity periods

  • Periods can't partially overlap. A period can be lengthened if it doesn't partially overlap another period.
  • Periods must be continuous. There can't be gaps between periods.

Cost center assignment

  • The validity period of a profit center assigned to a cost center must be equal to or longer than the validity period of the cost center.
  • Validity periods of profit centers assigned to cost centers cannot be shortened. However, a profit center validity period can be deleted, as long as the remaining validity periods of that profit center still cover the full validity period of the assigned cost center.
Postings
  • Periods can‚Äôt be shortened or deleted if they contain a posting.
  • Periods can‚Äôt be shortened if they share a fiscal year with a posting, whether it is within that specific period or not.

Example:

SAP Help Portal - Editing Validity Periods

Automatic Adjustments

To simplify work for users and reduce manual maintenance, the system can automatically adjust validity periods when creating or updating them. These adjustments include:
  • Splitting
  • Merging

Splitting

Splitting occurs when part of an existing validity period becomes part of a new validity period. This happens when you create a new validity period that falls entirely within an existing period but contains different time-based data. If these conditions are met, the system splits the validity periods automatically when you save the new period. Splitting only occurs when two validity periods interact, not three. You cannot create a new validity period that partially overlaps two existing periods. Postings do not affect splitting.

Example:

  • Original Validity Period: 11/01/2025 ‚Äì 12/31/2026
  • New Validity Period (different time-based fields): 11/01/2025 ‚Äì 12/31/2025
  • Outcome:
    • Period A: 11/01/2025 ‚Äì 12/31/2025
    • Period B: 01/01/2026 ‚Äì 12/31/2026

Steps to achieve Splitting:

Splitting - step 1Splitting - step 2Splitting - step 3Splitting - outcome

Note: The split can occur at the beginning, middle, or end of the original period. Partial overlaps are not allowed. The system automatically creates the resulting periods. More at SAP Help Portal.

Merging

Merging occurs when a new period and an existing period can be combined into a single period. This happens when both periods have identical time-based data and are either directly adjacent or the new period is fully contained within the existing period. If these conditions are met, the system merges the periods automatically when you save the changes. A partial overlap between two periods does not trigger merging. Postings do not affect merging.

Example:

  • Original Validity Period: 11/01/2025 ‚Äì 12/31/2025
  • New Validity Period (same time-based fields): 01/01/2026 ‚Äì 12/31/2026
  • Outcome:
    • Merged Period: 11/01/2025 ‚Äì 12/31/2026

Steps to achieve Merging:

MergingMerging - outcome

Note: Merging works only if the time-dependent fields are identical. Merging applies when periods are adjacent or new is fully contained within the original one. Partial overlaps cannot be merged. More at SAP Help Portal.

Conclusion

Managing validity periods is a core part of maintaining clean, reliable, and audit-ready profit center master data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. By understanding how periods are created, updated, and controlled (and how the system automatically handles splitting and merging) you can ensure that organizational changes are reflected accurately without disrupting historical reporting or future planning. With these principles in place, profit center maintenance becomes more consistent, predictable, and aligned with both business and compliance needs.

‰∏Ä.What is a Balance Sheet/ Income Statements?
This is a financial statement that outlines a company's financial position at a specific moment. It consists of three main components:

  1. Assets: The resources owned by a business, categorized into current assets (e.g., cash, accounts receivable, inventory) and non-current assets (e.g., buildings, machinery, intangible assets).

  2. Liabilities: The debts and obligations the company must repay, split into current liabilities (e.g., accounts payable, short-term loans) and long-term liabilities (e.g., long-term debt, bonds).

  3. Owner's Equity: Also known as shareholders' equity, it represents the residual interest in the assets of the company after deducting liabilities, typically comprising paid-in capital and retained earnings.

These elements are bound by the fundamental balance sheet equation: Assets = Liabilities + Owner‚Äôs Equity.

‰∫å.Data Retrieval Logic for "Undistributed Profits"
In the context of executing a period-end report, such as a Chinese balance sheet or profit and loss statement, understanding the data retrieval logic is essential, particularly for items like "Undistributed Profits." Users may often question the accuracy of this item, and verification can be approached systematically by examining the financial statement configuration:

  1. Configuration: "Undistributed Profits" is extracted from the retained earnings account and SAP's standard net profit nodes. Since the calculation nodes automate this process, one cannot drill down to transaction details directly from the balance sheet.

  2. Verification Process: Users should utilize tools such as "Display G/L Account Balances" to examine beginning, ending, and period transaction balances to ensure figures are accurate.

  3. Example Logic for Year-End Reports:
    As an example for executing the Chinese balance sheet/profit and loss statement for the end of 2024 and 2025, the data retrieval logic for the "Undistributed Profits" item is as follows:

    • "Undistributed Profits" balance at the beginning of 2024 = Retained earnings account balance at the beginning of 2024 + Net profit node's beginning balance (generally, after normal year-end closing, the net profit balance has been carried forward, so the beginning balance should be 0).

       

    • "Undistributed Profits" balance at the end of 2024 = Retained earnings account balance at the end of 2024 + Net profit balance for the year.

       

    • "Undistributed Profits" balance at the beginning of 2025 = Retained earnings account balance at the beginning of 2025 + Net profit node's beginning balance (generally, after normal year-end closing, the net profit balance has been carried forward, so the beginning balance should be 0).

       

    • "Undistributed Profits" balance at the end of 2025 = Retained earnings account balance at the end of 2024 + Net profit balance for the current year.

       

    • After proper year-end closing, the beginning balance for the "Undistributed Profits" item in 2025 should equal the ending balance for 2024, which means that the retained earnings account balance at the beginning of 2025 = retained earnings account balance at the end of 2024 + net profit for the 2024 period.

Conclusion

The data retrieval logic in a balance sheet, particularly for "Undistributed Profits," involves a blend of systematic configuration and thorough verification. By meticulously following these processes, companies can ensure the accuracy of their financial disclosures, ultimately aiding in informed decision-making.

entry.title: Understanding the "Account Document Output" App and Customizing Form Templates
entry.content:
The "Account Document Output" app is a powerful tool designed to streamline the display and printing of debit and credit postings for various general ledger accounts, in compliance with Chinese legal requirements. Here's a closer look at its functionality and how users can customize the forms to suit their specific needs.

‰∏Ä. What Does the "Account Document Output" App Do?
The main purpose of this app is to provide users with flexibility in displaying and printing accounting documents. It offers three output types: ALV list, PDF preview, and PDF direct printing. This versatility allows users to view accounting documents according to their preferences and needs. Key features of the app include:
a)Output Types: Users can choose between ALV list, PDF preview, and PDF direct printing for viewing accounting vouchers.
b)View Switching: Support for toggling between general ledger view and entry view.
c)Document Type Selection: Provides options for selecting different accounting document types.
d)Batch Printing: On the Cloud, users can set up printer queues and specify default print forms for direct batch printing of accounting documents.
‰∫å.Customization options while printing:
PDF Report Title, Accountant Manager, Approver: Users can specify headers and signature lines to appear during voucher printing.
Alternative Account Number: Supports the display of alternative account numbers when printing vouchers.
Batch Input Sorting Field: Users can set the sorting criteria when displaying accounting documents in batches, such as sorting by official voucher number by month.

entry.content:
Integrating SAP EHS Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side - Guidebook

Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

Table of Contents:

  • 1. Why is this Integration required?
  • 2. Prerequisites
  • 3. Technical Integration
  • 3.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Configuration
  • 3.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration
  • 3.2.1 Create Communication User
  • 3.2.2 Create Communication System
  • 3.2.3 Create Communication Arrangement
  • 3.3 SAP Integration Suite Configuration
  • 3.3.1Establishing the Event Queue for On-Premise Triggers
  • 3.3.2 Integration Credential Configuration
  • 3.3.3 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup - Equipment
  • 3.3.4 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup ‚Äì Functional Locations
  • 3.4 Monitoring
  • 3.4.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise
  • 3.4.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • 3.4.3 SAP Integration Suite
  • 4. Lessons Learned
  • 5. Engage with Us

Related Content:

Below is an overview of the planned blog series ‚Äì each post focusing on a specific integration topic. Once published, the titles will be linked for direct access:

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side ‚Äì Guidebook

Part 1: Introduction & OverviewLink
Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactorsLink
Part 3: Integration of Business Partners & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)Link
Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise SystemLink
Part 5: Extensibility Scenarios & Further ImplementationLink
Part 6: Summary & OutlookLink

 

1. Why is this Integration required?

Integrating Functional Locations and Equipment master data from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise into SAP EHS Public Cloud is a foundational step for enabling core EHS processes such as Risk Management, Incident Management, and Emissions Management. Instead of maintaining asset-related data manually within SAP EHS Public Cloud, the system relies on validated Plant Maintenance (PM) master data coming from the customer‚Äôs existing ERP landscape. This ensures that all structures, machines, and technical objects involved in EHS processes remain consistent, reliable, and audit-proof across the enterprise.

Accurate and up-to-date Functional Location and Equipment data is essential because many EHS processes depend on a clear understanding of where work is performed and which technical objects is affected. This includes:

  • Identifying the exact machine or installation involved in an incident
  • Linking hazards to the correct technical asset in Risk Assessments
  • Performing control inspections and assigning follow-up actions
  • Ensuring asset-specific exposure, material usage, or emission characteristics are correctly evaluated
  • Centralizing reporting across operational sites based on real asset hierarchies

In other words: Without integrated Functional Location and Equipment data, SAP EHS Public Cloud cannot reliably assess risks, evaluate hazards, track incidents, or produce compliant operational reports.

Architectural Approach - Scope

The highlighted section of the architectural diagram illustrates the scope relevant to this blog post ‚Äì focusing on the integration of Functional Locations and Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Reference to User Scenario (B) ‚Äì Risk Management

In part 1 ‚ÄúIntroduction & Overview‚Äù, the User Scenario (B) ‚Äì Risk Management at Mike Machineries (chapter 2.1.1) demonstrated why this integration is required:

Scenario Step

Why Plant Maintenance (PM) Integration Matters

A supervisor identifies a hazard in the chemical handling area

The hazard must be assigned to the correct Functional Location to ensure accurate traceability and reporting.

An Industrial Hygienist conducts a risk assessment

Equipment properties (e.g. ventilation units, storage cabinets, extraction systems) must be available from SAP PM to evaluate exposure and technical conditions.

Mitigation actions are defined

Some mitigation measures depend on technical object (e.g., upgrading ventilation, replacing equipment, updating signage).

A control inspection is performed

The inspection must reference the exact equipment or Functional Location where the mitigation is implemented.

Residual risk is recalculated

The correct asset hierarchy ensures that results are assigned to the right operational area or machine.

Results are shared with operations teams

Consistent Functional Location data ensures findings reach the correct plant, work center, or technical area.

Without integrated Functional Locations and Equipment, the system would not be able to:

  • Assign hazards or incidents to the correct asset
  • Trace risk assessments and inspections to the real technical environment
  • Evaluate machine-specific conditions and exposures
  • Monitor the effectiveness of mitigation actions at asset level
  • Ensure accurate reporting across operational areas and sites

Note: When implementing Risk Management as demonstrated in the user scenario, ensure that the relevant scope item 54A ‚Äì Health & Safety Management (for Risk Management) is activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Central Business Configuration (CBC). This activation enables the Risk Assessment and Control Inspection processes in SAP EHS Public Cloud so that synchronized Functional Locations and Equipment master data can be used consistently.

While this integration is mandatory for Risk Management, it is equally relevant for other EHS use cases such as Incident Management or Emissions Management. In all these processes, consistent asset data provides the foundation for identifying affected areas, assessing technical conditions, and enabling accurate regulatory reporting.

 

2. Prerequisites

To successfully integrate Plant Maintenance data from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via the SAP Integration Suite, the following prerequisites must be fulfilled:

Tenant Provisioning:  

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant 
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise tenant (with activated Plant Maintenance)
  • SAP Integration Suite tenant (Cloud Integration + Event Mesh)

Administrator Access: 

Ensure administrator users exist in all three systems: 

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: The administrator should have the template role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR assigned to allow the creation of communication users, systems, and arrangements. 
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise: Users with access to the SPRO are required.
  • SAP Integration Suite: A User with admin rights for Event Mesh and iFlow deployment is required.

Scope Item Activation:  

Following scope items need to be activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud:

  • 4HH ‚Äì Reactive Maintenance (mandatory for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud communication scenario regarding the inbound services for Equipment and Functional Locations).
  • 54A ‚Äì Health & Safety Management (required for Risk Management scenario).

Activated OData Services in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System:

  • API_EQUIPMENT and API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION active in SAP Gateway (check via /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE).

Event Mesh Instance:

  • Provisioned by SAP BTP with service key available (for AMQP connection).

These prerequisites ensure that the integration of Plant Maintenance ‚Äì specially changes made in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system ‚Äì operates smoothly and reliably, thereby supporting EHS processes such as Risk Management.

 

3. Technical Integration

This section provides an overview of the technical integration required to replicate Plant Maintenance master data from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud for EHS processes.

The integration scenario builds on the activation of the scope item 4HH ‚Äì Reactive Maintenance, which delivers the necessary inbound services for Equipment and Functional Locations in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. These objects form the foundation for EHS capabilities such as Risk Management, Incident Management, or Emissions Management.

The process shown in this integration scenario is event-driven. This means, whenever changes occur to Plant Maintenance master data, such as Equipment or Functional Location in the On-Premise system, these updates are automatically replicated to the Public Cloud. This approach keeps both systems aligned without manual steps or scheduled batch jobs, ensuring that asset information is always current.

Keeping master data synchronized between both systems is critical for effective Risk Management because risk assessments and mitigation strategies depend on accurate details about assets and their locations.

By ensuring that updates flow seamlessly between systems, organizations can make informed decisions and maintain compliance across their EHS processes.

Key Configuration Areas: 

  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Configuration 
  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration 
  • SAP Integration Suite Configuration
  • Monitoring

3.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Configuration

As this integration scenario for Functional Locations and Equipment is event driven, the creation of channels was required in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system to publish business events to the SAP Integration Suite via Event Mesh.

In this context the channels define the protocol (AMQP), destination (Event Mesh service key), and topic space.

Outbound bindings specify which event topics (e.g., sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/*) are sent. This ensures that changes in Functional Locations or Equipment trigger the corresponding iFlows in the SAP Integration Suite.

Channels can be created by navigating to SPRO > ABAP Platform > Enterprise Event Enablement > Administration > Chanel Connection Settings > Manage Channels and Parameters.

Therefore, we created the channel IS_INTERNAL_EVENTMESH which uses the AMQP Protocol.

Event Channels in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

After creating the channel, we added two outbound bindings to define which event topic should be published.

  • sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/*
  • sap/s4/beh/functionallocation/v1/FunctionalLocation/*

Added Outbound Bindings to created Event Channel

This configuration ensures that business events for Functional Locations and Equipment are reliably published from the on-premise system to SAP Integration Suite via Event Mesh, enabling event-driven iFlows without the need for polling.

3.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration

In addition to setting up SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must also be configured to receive employee master data via the SAP Integration Suite. 

For this purpose, a Communication Arrangement is required to enable secure data exchange between the systems. In this scenario, the predefined Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395 ‚Äì Asset Management Master Data Integration is used.

By activating and configuring this Communication Arrangement enables the necessary inbound API services, allowing the SAP Integration Suite to push employee data into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. 

To create the Communication Arrangement, we need to create a Communication User as well as a Communication System that will be assigned to the related Communication Arrangement.

3.2.1 Create Communication User

In this integration scenario, an Inbound Communication User was created in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (e.g., user OPN_IN). This user was used for Basic Authentication in the Communication Arrangement, and its credentials were securely stored in the Security Material of the SAP Integration Suite to enable a safe connection between the systems. 

Select Maintain Communication Users

To create the Inbound Communication User in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, log in to the Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the app ‚ÄúMaintain Communication Users‚Äù.  

Select "New"

If no suitable user exists, select ‚ÄúNew‚Äù to create one.

Created Communication User - General Data

The username and password for Basic Authentication can be freely defined. 

Related Communication System and Arrangements

Once created, the system automatically structures the user view, showing assignments to Communication Systems and Arrangements (added in later steps). 

3.2.2 Create Communication System

The Communication System is a necessary component for the Communication Arrangement. If you have already set up a Communication System for the S/4HANA On-Premise system, you can use it for the Communication Arrangement. Please note that the previously created Communication User must be assigned to this system for the following steps. Furthermore, no additional system-level settings (regarding outbound communication) are necessary, as the communication scenario SAP_COM_0395 only uses inbound services.

If no related user exists, you can create a new one as follows: Navigate to the S/4HANA Public Cloud app ‚ÄúCommunication Systems‚Äù.

Select Communication Systems

Select ‚ÄúNew‚Äù.

Select "New"

Enter a System ID and System Name referring to the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise tenant and proceed with the set up. 

Creating new Communication System

Select Inbound Only as the communication scenario SAP_COM_0395 only uses Inbound Communication.

Select Inbound Only

Assign the previously created Communication User.

Assign Communication User

3.2.3 Create Communication Arrangement

The final step in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud configuration is to bind the previously created components  (Communication User and Communication System) within the Communication Arrangement (SAP_COM_0395 ‚Äì Asset Management Master Data Integration). 

Once configured, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is ready to receive replicated Plant Maintenance master data (e. g. Functional Locations or Equipment) from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system through the SAP Integration Suite. The Communication Arrangement provides the inbound service URLs, which must be stored in the corresponding Integration Flow (iFlow) of the SAP Integration Suite to establish end-to-end communication. 

To create the arrangement, log in to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the ‚ÄúCommunication Arrangements‚Äù app. 

Select Communication Arrangements

Then click on ‚ÄúNew‚Äù to create a new Communication Arrangement. 

Select "New"

Select Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0395

Choose SAP_COM_0395 as the Communication Scenario.

Choose Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0395

After the creation of the Communication Arrangement the before created Communication System will be attached. Note that the corresponding Communication User will be determined automatically.

Communication System and User

The Inbound Service of the Communication Arrangement provides us then the Service URL, that will be used as the receiver endpoint in the iFlow configuration of the SAP Integration Suite.  

Required Inbound Services

3.3 SAP Integration Suite Configuration

In this integration scenario we used the SAP Integration Suite as the middleware layer to enable secure and reliable data exchange between the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Therefore, the SAP Integration Suite is responsible for retrieving Plant Maintenance master data (such as Functional Locations and Equipment) from the On-Premise system and delivering it to the Public Cloud using event-driven integration flows.

Since there is no pre-delivered integration package available for this scenario, we created two custom iFlows to handle the replication of Functional Location and Equipment data. Both iFlows follow a similar structure in terms of processing logic; however, they differ in the endpoints used for communication with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and the On-Premise system respectively.

Custom Integration Package for this Scenario

3.3.1 Establishing the Event Queue for On-Premise Triggers

The first step in this implementation is to create an Event Queue in SAP Event Mesh using the Message Client. This queue serves as the trigger point for event-driven integration. When a change occurs in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system (such as an update to Functional Locations or Equipment), an event is published to the queue.

The iFlow will be later subscribed to the Event Queue and use the event as a trigger to start processing. Once triggered, the iFlow calls the related API in the On-Premise system to retrieve the full master data for the affected object. This design ensures that updates are replicated to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud in near real-time, keeping both systems synchronized.

Note: The SAP Event Mesh ‚Äì Message client is typically provisioned by the BASIS administrator. If you have no existing Message Client, please refer to your BASIS team.

Once the message client was set up, navigate to it inside the SAP Integration Suite > Configure > Event Mesh.

Navigate to Message Client in SAP Integration Suite

Since our EHS scenario relates to Functional Locations and Equipment, we have created two separate event queues here. Therefore, select Create.

Select "Create"

Enter a name for the new Event Queue(e. g. opn.equipment). You can keep the remaining fields as default.

Queue Settings for opn.equipment

Then navigate to Subscriptions and select Create.

Select "Create"

Two Topic Subscriptions were required within the Event Queue Details for the Equipment:

  • <message-client-prefix>/ce/sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/Created/v1
  • <message-client-prefix>/de/ce/sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/Changed/v1

Note: Regarding the Subscription, the message-client-prefix will be typically provisioned by your BASIS team. The remaining part of the respective topic names of the Equipment event is SAP standard and can be viewed in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub in the tab Event References Event References | Equipment Events | SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Repeat this step also for the Functional Location. Therefore again, enter a name for the new event queue (e. g. opn.FuncLoc). The following subscriptions are needed for this event queue:

  • <message-client-prefix>/ce/sap/s4/beh/functionallocation/v1/FunctionalLocation/Changed/v1
  • <message-client-prefix>/ce/sap/s4/beh/functionallocation/v1/FunctionalLocation/Created/v1

The Functional Location events for the Functional Locations can be found in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub in the tab Event References Event References | Functional Location Events | SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

3.3.2 Integration Credential Configuration

Within the SAP Integration Suite, the created integration flows (iFlows) must authenticate against three endpoints:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud ‚Äì to push the synchronized data to the cloud system.
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise ‚Äì to retrieve Functional Location and Equipment data
  • SAP Event Mesh ‚Äì to consume events via AMQP protocol and trigger the integration process.

Note: To ensure secure authentication for each endpoint used by the iFlow, a dedicated Security Material object was created for every connection. In our demo environment, Basic Authentication was sufficient; however, for productive landscapes, certificate-based authentication is required to meet security standards and comply with enterprise policies.

For communication with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, Basic Authentication was used in this scenario. The credentials of the Inbound Communication User from SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must therefore be maintained as Security Material within the SAP Integration Suite. This configuration ensures that the integration flow can authenticate securely when transmitting data to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Security Material

The Security Material that was used for communication with the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system, was created in a similar way using Basic Authentication, based on the credentials of the On-Premise user. Note that the On-Premise user will be provided by your SAP BASIS team.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Security Material

For the Event Mesh Security Material that enables communication with SAP Event Mesh, OAuth 2.0 was used for authentication. Therefore, enter the Token Service URL, Client ID and Client Secret, which are provided by the service key of your SAP Event Mesh Instance in SAP BTP Cockpit.

SAP Integration Suite - Event Mesh Security Material

3.3.3 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup - Equipment

Regarding the iFlows we will setup the Equipment Integration iFlow first. Therefore, create the iFlow with a corresponding name, set SAP S/4HANA as Sender and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as Receiver.

Sender and Receiver Setup for Equipment iFlow

The integration flow starts with an AMQP connection to SAP Event Mesh. This connection allows the iFlow to subscribe to event queues and consume messages whenever Functional Location or Equipment changes occur in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system. The AMQP protocol ensures reliable, event-driven communication between the systems and acts as the trigger for the subsequent OData calls.

Therefore, connect the Receiver with the Start Message using the Adapter Type AMQP with Websocket as Transport Protocol.

First iFlow Step - AMQP Adapter Setup

The General tab inside the Adapter can stay as default. In the Connection tab you need to add a Host, Port and Path of the Event Mesh Service Key. You will find this Service Key in the Event Mesh Instance of your SAP BTP Cockpit. For Authentication use OAuth 2.0 and add the associated Security Material for Event Mesh (created in the previous step) as Credential Name.

AMQP Adapter Connection Setup

AMQP Adapter Connection Setup

In the Processing tab, add the event queue name for the equipment.

Assign Event Queue opn.equipment to AMQP Adapter

The incoming event message from SAP Event Mesh is delivered in JSON format. Since subsequent processing steps and OData calls require XML, the JSON to XML Converter transforms the payload accordingly. In this scenario, namespace mapping is disabled because the JSON structure does not include namespaces that need to be preserved in the XML output. The remaining parts of the Converter can stay as default.

JSON to XML Converter

After the conversion to XML, we added a Content Modifier. This Content Modifier is used to extract specific values from the XML structure and store them as Message Header and Exchange Properties.

Content Modifier Setup - General

In the Message Header tab, the Content Modifier reads values from the XML payload using XPath and sets them as message headers. In our example, we set the SAP_ApplicationID header with the Functional Location value found at /root/data/Equipment in the XML.

Content Modifier Setup - Message Header

In the Exchange Property tab, the Content Modifier creates two properties by extracting values from the XML payload using XPath: p_eventType from /root/type and p_equipmentno from /root/data/Equipment. These properties are later used to dynamically build the OData request URL for the GET call to the on-premise system.

Content Modifier Setup - Exchange Property

Next, we set a Request Reply with the name Get Equipment Data. This enables us to get the data via OData Adapter from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system.

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System

In the Connection tab of the OData adapter, we define how the integration flow connects to the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system. In our example, the address consists of the virtual host and port provided by the SAP Cloud Connector, followed by the OData service path /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_EQUIPMENT/, which is the standard endpoint for the Equipment API in SAP Gateway. The proxy type is set to ‚ÄúOn-Premise‚Äù, and the Location ID refers to the configured Cloud Connector destination (can be found in the Master Instance for your Cloud Connector in the SAP BTP Cockpit > Logged in into your Subaccount > Connectivity > Cloud Connectors). Regarding the authentication, was used with the on-premise related Security Material.

Note: We leveraged an existing SAP Cloud Connector configuration to securely connect the SAP Integration Suite to the on-premise system without exposing the real backend host.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Connection

Note that the API_EQUIPMENT is activated in your on-premise system. You can check this via the transaction /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE and searching for the API_EQUIPMENT OData Service.  

In the Processing tab, we configured a GET operation to the Resource Path Equipment. Therefore, click Select.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing

Choose Connection Source Remote. The fields will be automatically filled with the provided data in the Connection tab. Then click on Step 2. If the connection is configured correctly, we will configure the operation and entities here.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 1

Then select the operation ‚ÄúGET‚Äù, the Select Entity ‚ÄúEquipment‚Äù, the Sub Levels 1 and choose ‚ÄúSelect All Fields‚Äù.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 2

To retrieve only the changes for the specific Equipment Number, apply a filter on the property ${property.p_equipmentno} that was set in the Content Modifier earlier. Filter for the ValidityEndDate as shown below.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 3

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 4

After retrieving the equipment data from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system, we ensured with a message mapping step that the structure and fields of the incoming data match with the expected values for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. For our related message mapping we used a predefined mapping resource (/MM.mmap) created in the iFlow to transform the received data to the expected structure.

Message Mapping 1

Message Mapping 2

After completing the mapping as required for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Equipment Inbound Service, we set a new Request Reply with an OData V2 adapter to the receiver endpoint of the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System

In the Connection tab add the inbound service URL for the Equipment provided by the Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395 in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Inbound Service URL for Equipment in Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395

Choose Proxy Type Internet and add your Security Material that was created for communication with the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Basic Authentication.

As we want to send the structure which the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system expects, we need to create new processing details for this OData Adapter. Therefore, choose the Processing tab and navigate to Select.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing

Choose again the Connection Source Remote. The required details to connect with the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system will be shown here again automatically after the previous details in the Connection tab have been configured. Then navigate to Step 2.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 1

Now choose the Operation Post, Entity Equipment, Sub Levels 1 and Select All Fields. For the Post operation no filters are required.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 2

Note: The iFlow also shows an Exception Subprocess. You can perform this after the implementation of the iFlow is finished. In our scenario we let the Exception Subprocess empty.

Exception Subprocess

3.3.4 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup ‚Äì Functional Locations

The iFlow for the Functional Locations was similar in architecture, with small changes.

Created iFlow for Functional Location

For the AMQP Adapter at beginning of the iFlow, the event queue for Functional Location was used.

Used Event Queue in iFlow Funcional Location

According to Content Modifier > Message Header, the used Source Value was /root/data/FunctionalLocation.

Content Modifier in iFlow Functional Location - Message Header

In the Exchange Property tab of the Content Modifier, we changed the second line entry to the Name p_functionallocation and its Source Value to /root/data/FunctionalLocation.

Content Modifier in iFlow Functional Location - Exchange Property

According to the Get Functional Location Data that will perform a GET operation to the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system, we used the OData Service for ‚ÄúAPI_FUNCTIONALLOCATION‚Äù with the root address /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION/. Note again that the API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION is activated in your on-premise system. You can check this via the transaction /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE and searching for the API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION OData Service. 

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System

In the Processing tab navigate to Select and go to Step 2 (As the fields required for the system connection will be filled automatically).

Choose the Operation and Select Entity as shown below with Sub Level 1 and Select All Fields.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration

Regarding the query, we were only filtering for FunctionalLocationLabelName equals ${property.p_functionallocation}.

The Message Mapping now needs to be performed for the Functional Location. Therefore, we used again the Resource /MM.mmap but now with a new mapping.

Message Mapping 1

Message Mapping 2

For the last OData Adapter sending the transformed Functional Location data from the SAP Integration Suite to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Inbound Service URL for the Functional Location was used in the Address Field of the Connection Details.

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System - Connection

Inbound Service URL for Equipment in Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395

According to the Processing details, the connection to the system will be again filled automatically. Then Navigate to Step 2 and choose the Select Entity as well as the Operation as shown below. Choose again Select All Fields.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration

3.4 Monitoring

Monitoring is a critical part of ensuring that event-driven integration for EHS Risk Management runs reliably across SAP S/4HANA (Public Cloud & On-Premise) and the SAP Integration Suite. Accurate and timely event processing is essential because many risk-related processes depend on these events. Missing or delayed events can lead to incomplete risk assessments, gaps in safety measures, and potential compliance violations.

The Monitoring can be performed at all three involved systems.

3.4.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

Regarding the Outbound Events that are sent from the on-premise system to the SAP Integration Suite, you can navigate to SPRO > ABAP Platform > Enterprise Event Enablement > Monitoring > Monitor Event Queues.

If any failures for the Outbound Events occur, they can be analyzed here.

Event Monitor in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System

3.4.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, monitoring focuses on API communication rather than event queues. The primary tool that can be used here is the ‚ÄúOData Error Log‚Äù app, which provides detailed error messages for failed OData requests. This is essential for troubleshooting issues when SAP Integration Suite sends data to the Public Cloud system.

OData Error Log in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System

3.4.3 SAP Integration Suite

SAP Integration Suite provides several tools to track and manage integrations flows. As already described already in the part 2 you can therefore navigate within the SAP Integration Suite to Monitor > Overview > Manage Integration Content. Here you can select your respective iFlow (e.g. ‚ÄúFunctional Location Integration in between SAP S4HANA and SAP S4HANA Cloud‚Äù) and select Monitor Message Processing.

Manage Integration Content for Functional Location iFlow

This view provides a clear overview of the processing status for each message, indicating whether it was completed successfully or if any errors occurred during execution.

Monitor Message Processing

By selecting Message Status Overview on the upper right corner,  statistics will be shown across all processed messages, including completed, failed and retried executions. This provides a consolidated view of the integration scenario over a selected timeframe and supports quick identification of patterns or recurring issues. 

Message Status Overview

 

4. Lessons Learned

Implementing this integration scenario via the scope item 4HH for Plant Maintenance data (such as Functional Locations or Equipment) from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provided several valuable insights that are highly relevant for similar integration projects.

1. Event-Driven Integration Ensures Real-Time Accuracy: Using SAP Event Mesh with AMQP is critical for keeping Functional Location and Equipment data synchronized. Batch jobs cannot guarantee timely updates for EHS processes like Risk Management.

2. Validate OData Services Early: Missing activation of API_EQUIPMENT or API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION in the on-premise system is a common root cause for iFlow failures. Always check via /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE before starting.

3. Topic Naming in Event Mesh Requires Precision: Incorrect prefixes or typos in topic subscriptions will block event processing entirely. Always cross-check against SAP Business Accelerator Hub references.

4. Message Mapping Is Compliance-Critical: Ensure that Equipment and Functional Location data is transformed correctly for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Missing mandatory fields can lead to incomplete risk assessments and reporting gaps.

5. Monitoring Is Essential for Operational Reliability: Event-driven integration depends on timely message processing. Use monitoring tools in all three systems (SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, SAP Integration Suite, and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud) to detect and resolve issues early.

6. Plan Authentication Strategy Upfront: Basic Authentication works for demos, but production environments require certificate-based authentication. Delaying this switch can cause project delays and security risks.

 

5. Engage with Us

To follow the series, make sure to subscribe to the SAP EHS Public Cloud blog tag.

We welcome your thoughts and feedback in the comments!
